'''Miles Menander Dawson''' (May 13, 1863 - 1942) was an American author of poetry and philosophy, and ethics. He wrote books about the teachings of [[Zoroaster]], [[Socrates]], and [[Confucius]]. He was a member of the [[Confucian Society of China]].<ref>{{cite book |author= |coauthors= |title=The Ethics of Confucius |year=2002 |publisher=[[University Press of the Pacific]] |page= |quote= | url=http://www.amazon.com/Ethics-Confucius-Miles-Menander-Dawson/dp/1410203565 |isbn=1-4102-0356-5 }}</ref>

==Biography==
He was born in [[Viroqua, Wisconsin]] on May 13, 1863.<ref>{{cite web |url= |title=[[:File:Miles Menander Dawson 1908 passport.jpeg|Miles Menander Dawson passport application from April 20, 1908]] |accessdate=2010-07-30 |quote= |publisher=[[United States Department of State]] }}</ref> Dawson worked as an [[actuary]] in [[New York City]]. He wrote numerous books and articles on life insurance and actuarial science.<ref name=life/> In 1905 and 1910 he acted as a lobbyist when bills were being prepared to regulate the insurance industry.<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Insurance Bills Guided To Death |url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9404E2D91430E233A25756C2A9659C946196D6CF |quote=They were accompanied by the charge of Miles Menander Dawson, that in 1905, when Dawson was before the Legislature the passage of a bill affecting life ... |work=[[New York Times]] |date=May 25, 1910 |accessdate=2010-07-30 }}</ref>

He died in 1942.
